Abraham was an archimandrite of
Arʿa Rabtha

Maro was an archimandrite of
Arʿa Rabtha

event.desc: After laboring for ten years in the monastery, Abraham stood on a column to pray and fast.
After mighty labors of abstinence, Abraham received gifts of the Spirit that enabled him to cure the sick and to drive out demons.
Maro also received gifts of the Spirit, but refused to perform exorcisms, instead he decided to enclose himself in a tree in the monastery and live as a hermit and ascetic.
Because Maro's ascetic practices were so extreme and sometimes dangerous, Abraham convinced him to return to the shelter of the monastery.

personGrp.persName:
Persons who came to be healed by
Abraham

event.desc: The two brothers gained a great deal of fame.
Abraham died after thirty-eight years standing on the column.
Maro took Abraham's place on the column so that his brother's place would not be empty.
Maro prayed that his time on the column would not be a torment, but a conductor to life.
John's parents visited the holy Maro and asked him to save his life, as all of his brothers and sisters died in infancy.
Maro bid a certain brother to fetch lentils for the baby John to eat

person.persName:
A certain brother who fetched lentils for
John

event.desc: John, who appeared dead, was revived by eating the lentils provided by Maro.
Maro made John's parents promise to bring him back in two years to be raised in the monastery
After two years, John's parents brought him to Maro to be raised in the monastery.
Maro's fame grew as he became known for performing blessings and miracles through prayer.

Maro explained to the people that he would not perform exorcisms because they are a means by which deceitful fiends possess the innocent in order to trick exorcists and healers into believing that they are more powerful than they really are--causing them to fall into the trap of pride and vainglory.
A certain layman whose wife was barren came to Maro for help. Maro gave him one of his toenails to hang on his wife, who then promptly conceived a son.

person.persName: A certain layman whose wife was barren

event.desc: A certain magistrate from the same village as Maro was an evil man who oppressed widows, orphans, and other unfortunate people.
Maro warned the magistrate against abusing his authority and the magistrate ignored him.
Fire came down from heaven and burned the magistrate's house down.
Maro sent a presbyter to check on the magistrate and discovered that he, his slaves, and his wife barely escaped the fire with their lives.

event.desc: The magistrate fell ill and died
The magistrate's wife went blind
the magistrate's wife died.
Some of the magistrate's slaves died.
Maro used the story of the fall of the magistrate and his household as a warning against pride.
After twenty years, Maro received a vision of the invasion of the Huns.
Maro's companions refused to abandon him.

personGrp.persName:
The blessed man's companions who would not abandon
Maro

event.desc: The Huns invaded but the monastery was protected and left unharmed because of Maro's prayers.
After forty years of labor, Maro died.
